basics.name: Jiong Xiao
basics.label: Final Year MA Cognitive Science Student
basics.summary: I was born in Fuzhou, China. I came to the University of Edinburgh for my undergraduate degree in Cognitive Science. I am interested in almost every question that can be asked about how the mind works. I am particularly enthusiastic about simulating higher-level cognitive processes via computational approaches.

work.name: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

education.institution: University of Edinburgh, Scotland, United Kingdoms

awards.title: Simon Gray Prize
awards.awarder: School of Philosophy, Psychology and Language Sciences, Edinburgh
awards.summary: The Prize was rewarded for outstanding performance in the 1st year philosophy course'

awards.title: Matthew Green Prize
awards.awarder: School of Philosophy, Psychology and Language Sciences, Edinburgh
awards.summary: The Prize was rewarded for achieving the highest marks in the 2nd psychology courses'

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
